bioghist.head: Historical or Biographical Note

note.p: The historical or biographical note provides background information about the creator of the material. It does not indicate the contents of the collection. Description of collection contents are found in the Collection and Series level Scope and Contents notes.

bioghist.p: Frederick Arthur Masse, Jr. (circa 1931- April 25, 1987) received his B.A. from Tufts in English in 1952 (A 1952). Masse spelled his name Massé and also used the pseudonyms Frederick Grimes Massé, Frederick A. P. Grimes Massé, and Arthur Jones MacMahon. During his life, Masse taught in Ethiopia, Iran, Sudan, Great Britain and Newport, RI. Masse was an English teacher for the Ministry of Fine Arts and Education in Addis Ababa 1958-1961 and 1963-1966. During this time he also served as tutor to two of Emperor Hailie Selassie's grandchildren. In 1962-1963 Masse taught high school in Khartoum. He served as a visiting lecturer in English as a Foreign Language at Georgetown University in the summer of 1975. From 1976 to circa 1978 he taught for the Imperial Iranian Navy. After retiring as a teacher, he lived in Miami, Florida.
Masse married Margaret Page (Margaret M. Massé), a Howard University graduate, in November 1970, but they were divorced by 1978.

References: Frederick Grimes Massé, Correspondence, vol. 2; Frederick Grimes Massé, preface to "Royal Bastards and Freed Slaves"; Tufts Criterion, Feb. 1971, p. 17; Tufts Criterion, Nov. 1975, p.11; Tufts Criterion, Oct. 1977, p. 13; Tufts Criterion, Summer 1987, p. 30.

scopecontent.head: Collection Scope and Content

note.p: The collection scope and content note provides general information about the contents of the collection. More detailed information about the collection can be found in Series Descriptions.

scopecontent.p: This collection contains Frederick A. Masse's personal correspondence and an autobiographical text, "Royal Bastards and Freed Slaves Volume 1."

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Some records may be restricted. See the DCA's General Policy on Access for more information about access to records, especially official University records.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections. Please see the DCA's policy on Copyright and Fair Use for more information.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Frederick A. Masse, Jr., papers, 1978-1986, Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

note.p: The series description provides more detailed information about the contents of each individual series. For a more general description of the collection as a whole, please see the Collection Scope and Content note.

scopecontent.p: This series contains an autobiographical text covering part of Frederick A. Masse's time in Ethiopia (1960-1961). It also includes photocopies of his personal correspondence which he bound in volumes. The series contains volumes 2-5. Volumes, 1, 6 and 7 are missing.

did.unittitle: Autobiographical Trilogy on living in Ethiopia, "Royal Bastards and Freed Slaves Volume 1"1980

note.p: Text consists of journal entries from 1960-61, but Masse organized and copyrighted the material in 1980.
